newsitem.title: GERMANY: Coffee roaster KJS thinking about price rise.
newsitem.headline: Coffee roaster KJS thinking about price rise.

text.p: German coffee roaster Kraft Jacobs Suchard (KJS), part of Philip Morris, said on Friday it could not rule out further retail prices increases in its roasted coffee products.
Citing persistently high green coffee prices, spokesman Rolf Sauerbier said, "Give us another week to decide on the details."
The company, which is the German market leader, has raised the average price per 500 grams of its roasted coffee products by 2.50 marks ex-works since March.
Most other roasters copied KJS's move in full.
Sauerbier said wholesale traders and groceries had not yet passed on the full effect of the price increase to the end consumers due to competitive pressures.
In the first quarter of 1997 KJS accounted for 30 percent of German coffee retail sales.
A spokeswoman for the Melitta group in Minden said the company believed prices should be higher but the market would resist attempts to raise them.
"There are no talks underway on this subject," she said.
Melitta Kaffee GmbH is the fourth largest roaster but its aggressive pricing policy can tilt the market one way or the other.
Other companies were not immediately available for comment on a day wedged between a public holiday on Thursday and the forthcoming weekend.
